awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Intraspecific variation in pathogen load in virus-infected birds: role of extrinsic and intrinsic factors
awd_abstract_narration: In the last century, there has been an unprecedented increase in the number of emerging infectious diseases that pose significant risks to wild and domestic animal and human populations. Moreover, greater than 60% of all human infectious diseases have originated in animals, including West Nile virus and avian influenza virus, for which birds serve as the sources. A prominent knowledge gap in disease epidemiology is an understanding of the factors that influence variation in infectiousness of individuals. This project has four main objectives: (1) Test how variation in host body condition, through food restriction, affects how a bird responds to West Nile virus, using American robin (Turdus migratorius) as a focal species. (2) Use genome-wide technologies to investigate how gene expression mediates variation in viral shedding using low pathogenic avian influenza virus and two species of waterfowl, the mallard (Anas platyrhynchos) and blue-winged teal (A. discors). (3) Develop simulation models that are parameterized with the data collected in experiments to investigate the effects of individual variation on pathogen dynamics at the population level. (4) Adapt the models to allow college, non-STEM students in general sciences to learn about disease dynamics.  Through a user-friendly computer interface students will be able to manipulate environmental stressors associated with climate change and/or other anthropogenic disturbances, and then track disease outcomes that are host and pathogen specific. Implementing a computer simulation exercise that illustrates concepts taught throughout the semester and allows students to answer relevant and thought-provoking questions will improve a student's learning experience in the large class environment. Overall this CAREER project will increase the understanding about the basis for variation in pathogen load and also which individuals may shed the highest pathogen loads (i.e. 'supershedders'), allowing development of more realistic epidemiological models that lead to cost-effective, targeted prevention and control strategies.

por.por_cntn:
During a disease outbreak there are individuals in a population that are more infectious and/or have higher pathogen (i.e., a disease-causing agent, such as virus or bacteria) load than others. This disparity is best illustrated by ‘superspreaders’; the individuals that are responsible for most of the pathogen transmission within a population. The superspreader phenomenon has been observed in many disease outbreaks. But what makes an individual a superspreader? Is it genetically determined? Does it arise from host-environment environment interaction? With the current NSF Career award, we aimed to gain greater insight into the source of variation in pathogen load in wild birds. We used two avian host-pathogen systems – low pathogenic avian influenza virus (LPAIV) and waterfowl (i.e., mallards and blue-winged teal) and West Nile virus (WNV) and a passerine bird (i.e., American robin).

To examine the intrinsic basis for variation in pathogen load, we used LPAIV-infected waterfowl. We found that variation in the availability of the viral receptors on the host tissue in the lower intestine positively corresponds to the amount of virus shed by an individual duck. Using transcriptomics, we examined differential gene expression relative to species, infection, days post-infection, and pathogen load. Prior to the current study, there was only a reference transcriptome for mallard but not blue-winged teal. Hence, we developed the reference transcriptome for blue-winged teals that can be used by scientists interested in waterfowl, influenza virus, and/or host-pathogen interactions. Taking a bioinformatics approach, we found that the amount of virus shed by a bird is linked to gene expression associated with the host’s early innate immune response. We further identified genes and pathways that are closely tied to pathogen load which allows for more targeted investigations in the future.  

Pathogens harbored by wildlife can pose significant risk to human health; simultaneously, human activities can significantly alter infection dynamics in wild reservoir populations, which may magnify human health risk. Unpredictable changes in food availability for wild organisms are one outcome of land-use change. In the current NSF Career award, we demonstrated that when American robins, an important avian reservoir host for West Nile virus, experience short-term food deprivation, they are more infectious than non-stressed robins. Further, we illustrated the epidemiological significance of this higher infectivity using an agent-based model that simulates transmission dynamics of West Nile virus between birds and a mosquito vector. When birds are experiencing acute food deprivation, they are more likely to infect mosquitoes, amplifying local transmission of West Nile virus. The study illustrates the key tenet of One Health, – the interdependence of the health of humans, wildlife, and the ecosystem

The current NSF Career award developed three client-side dynamic web applications, designed for for high school and university students that allows them opportunity to visualize scientific data and test hypotheses related to infectious disease dynamics. The purpose of these simulations was to illustrate how different environmental factors, socioeconomic status, human behavior, and population demographics can alter the dynamics of disease outbreaks and disease burden on a population. In the Human Malaria Dynamics simulation, the user can test hypotheses about the synergistic and antagonistic impacts of climate change and socioeconomic status on human risk of malaria is sub-Saharan Africa. In the Covid19 Dynamics simulation, the user can explore how human behavior and compliance with disease mitigation strategies (i.e., masks and social distancing) affects virus transmission and how age affects mortality rates.  At the time this award ended, the simulations had been the focus of learning modules for six courses in integrative environmental science and introductory math over three years, reaching over 1500 undergraduate students. The simulations are publicly available on a dedicated website and have teaching materials associated with each module. Further, the simulations led to additional grant funding for a multi-disciplinary team of faculty at Michigan State University to develop teaching modules that help students better understand how social determinants of health and health inequities can affect infectious disease outcomes.  

This NSF Career award provided significant training and educational experiences for over 25 undergraduate students, including three REUs, two graduate students, and one post-doctoral scientist. Many of the students were from under-represented groups in this discipline.

 


Last Modified: 10/03/2021
Modified by: Jen C Owen
